title: Gold struggles as dollar trades at more-than-2-year high
text:
Gold was lower Friday, heading for a weekly loss, as it failed to find haven-related support and the U.S. dollar continued to push higher.

Gold for December delivery GCZ19, -0.90% on Comex declined $14.70, or 1%, to $1,500.50 an ounce, while December silver SIZ19, -2.05% was off 37.7 cents, or 2.1%, at $17.535 an ounce.

The metal, a traditional haven, has lost ground despite a new round of U.S. political drama. A whistleblower report released on Thursday alleged that President Donald Trump attempted to coerce Ukraine to investigate Democratic rival Joe Biden, and that White House officials acted to conceal evidence of his actions. The controversy around the report prompted House Democrats this week to launch a formal impeachment inquiry. Indeed, markets overall have seen only a fleeting impact overall.

“Interestingly, gold has fallen since the impeachment proceedings were announced with investors preferring the dollar as protection from political uncertainty,” said Jasper Lawler, head of research at London Capital Group, in a note.

Gold remains up more than 17% in the year to date, with gains tied by many analysts to escalations in the U.S.-China trade war and other geopolitical tensions. Lawler, however, said the recent price action undermines that argument.

“This firms up our view that the rally in gold prices this year has not primarily been a function of haven flows but as protection from currency devaluation. As such we think overall impeachment is neutral for gold,” he said.

The ICE U.S. Dollar Index DXY, +0.03%, a measure of the U.S. currency against a basket of six major rivals, was little changed at 99.156 but holding near a more-than-two-year high. The index is up 0.7% this week.

In other metals trade, January platinum PLF20, -1.57% fell 1.5% to $928.10 an ounce, while December palladium PAZ19, -0.98% shed 1% to $1,625 an ounce.

December copper futures HGZ19, +0.56% were up 0.7% at $2.5955 a pound.
description: Gold heads for a weekly loss, failing to find haven-related support as the U.S. dollar flexes its muschles.
